elements.content: The interaction of zinc(II) or cadmium(II) sulfate with 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) or 4,4′-bipyridinethane (bpe) in the presence of 1,2-cyclohexanedionedioxime (NioxH2) resulted in four novel polymeric compounds with the compositions {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ (1), {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·0.5H2O·DMF}∞ (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) (2), [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3), and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4). Compounds were characterized by spectroscopic techniques and single crystal X-ray method. The chiral layer coordination polymer is the robust structural motif in 2–4. Although compounds 3 and 4 were isolated in the same crystallization conditions, the layers of opposite chirality constitute the achiral (3), and the layers of the same chirality result in chiral (4) architectures. All materials display blue luminescence upon excitation with ultraviolet light.

Although compounds 3 and 4 were isolated in the same crystallization conditions, the layers of opposite chirality constitute the achiral (3), and the layers of the same chirality result in chiral (4) architectures. All materials display blue luminescence upon excitation with ultraviolet light.

elements.content: Nowadays, the research interest on transition metal-based coordination polymers and porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is increasing rapidly because of their potential applications in the areas of materials chemistry such as catalysis, nonlinear optics, electronics, photoluminescence, and adsorption. Interpenetration in porous MOFs may greatly reduce the volume of pores. Thus, an investigation of the correlation between the porosity and the interpenetration and tuning the degree of interpenetration of the network via modification of ligands or via postsynthetic covalent modification of MOFs is a challenge for synthetic chemists. To overcome the current limitations of this class of materials, some extensive research reports have contributed to elaborating low-dimensional coordination compounds with the wheel-and-axle (WAA) geometry, which similar to MOFs are capable to accommodate small molecules. We recently reported the first examples mediated by the bypiridyl ligands binuclear Cu(II) dioximates and also binuclear and one-dimensional (1D) polymeric Zn(II) and Cd(II) dioximes with the WAA topology. We have shown that the single-charged formate and acetate anions and doubly charged sulfate anions coordinated to the metal center have different impacts on the final structure. For instance, in the 1D ladder type coordination polymer with the composition {[Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·(NioxH2)·3H2O}∞, an extended binuclear metal-dioxime building block is held by the two μ2-oxygen atoms of two SO4 2– anions, while in the dioxime-free homochiral 1D coordination polymer with the composition {[M(SO4)(bpy)]·3H2O}∞, the monodentate mode of the sulfate coordination has been registered for both Zn(II) and Cd(II) metals. The diversity of the SO4 2– anion coordination modes to the Cd(II)/Zn(II) metal centers in the coordination polymers with the dipyridyl type ligands is well documented. For example, these modes include the combination of both μ2 and μ3 bridging in the three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Cd2(bpy)2(H2O)3(SO4)2]·3H2O}∞ with NLO properties, the μ4-sulfate bridging for [Cd(SO4)(bpy)]∞, and [Cd(SO4)(bpethy]∞ [bpethy = bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne], while in {[Zn3(bpy)3(H2O)6(SO4)4](H2-bpy)·10H2O}∞ of two crystallographically independent sulfate groups, one acts in monodentate, while another functions in anti–anti bidentate modes. In the recently reported coordination compounds with 2-pyridyl ketone oxime, the sulfate anion shows a varied behavior (terminal, μ2-, and μ3-coordination). The diversity of the final structures illustrates the influence of different synthetic conditions (hydrothermal,microwave, or solution methods), adjusting the molar ratio of precursors or the pH value of the solution to further design and construct novel supramolecular assemblies with distinct structural features.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, the research interest on transition metal-based coordination polymers and porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is increasing rapidly because of their potential applications in the areas of materials chemistry such as catalysis, nonlinear optics, electronics, photoluminescence, and adsorption. Interpenetration in porous MOFs may greatly reduce the volume of pores. Thus, an investigation of the correlation between the porosity and the interpenetration and tuning the degree of interpenetration of the network via modification of ligands or via postsynthetic covalent modification of MOFs is a challenge for synthetic chemists. To overcome the current limitations of this class of materials, some extensive research reports have contributed to elaborating low-dimensional coordination compounds with the wheel-and-axle (WAA) geometry, which similar to MOFs are capable to accommodate small molecules. We recently reported the first examples mediated by the bypiridyl ligands binuclear Cu(II) dioximates and also binuclear and one-dimensional (1D) polymeric Zn(II) and Cd(II) dioximes with the WAA topology. We have shown that the single-charged formate and acetate anions and doubly charged sulfate anions coordinated to the metal center have different impacts on the final structure. For instance, in the 1D ladder type coordination polymer with the composition {[Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]⋅(NioxH2)⋅3H2O}∞, an extended binuclear metal-dioxime building block is held by the two μ2-oxygen atoms of two SO4 2- anions, while in the dioxime-free homochiral 1D coordination polymer with the composition {[M(SO4)(bpy)]⋅3H2O}∞, the monodentate mode of the sulfate coordination has been registered for both Zn(II) and Cd(II) metals. The diversity of the SO4 2- anion coordination modes to the Cd(II)/Zn(II) metal centers in the coordination polymers with the dipyridyl type ligands is well documented. For example, these modes include the combination of both μ2 and μ3 bridging in the three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymer {[Cd2(bpy)2(H2O)3(SO4)2]⋅3H2O}∞ with NLO properties, the μ4-sulfate bridging for [Cd(SO4)(bpy)]∞, and [Cd(SO4)(bpethy]∞ [bpethy = bis(4-pyridyl)ethyne], while in {[Zn3(bpy)3(H2O)6(SO4)4](H2-bpy)⋅10H2O}∞ of two crystallographically independent sulfate groups, one acts in monodentate, while another functions in anti-anti bidentate modes. In the recently reported coordination compounds with 2-pyridyl ketone oxime, the sulfate anion shows a varied behavior (terminal, μ2-, and μ3-coordination). The diversity of the final structures illustrates the influence of different synthetic conditions (hydrothermal,microwave, or solution methods), adjusting the molar ratio of precursors or the pH value of the solution to further design and construct novel supramolecular assemblies with distinct structural features.

elements.content: Encouraged by our previous results and the structural diversity that demonstrates the system MSO4 (M = Zn, Cd)–bipyridyl ligands in dependence on the ratio of the starting components, we undertook the present study and report herein the preparation, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of 1D coordination polymer {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ (1), and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·0.5H2O·DMF}∞ (2), [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3), and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4) (Scheme ). The chiral layer is the robust structural motif generated through the tetrahedral sulfate anions and bipyridine linkers in 2–4. The potential porosity of 2–4 was estimated using PLATON facilities.
elements.clean_text: Encouraged by our previous results and the structural diversity that demonstrates the system MSO4 (M = Zn, Cd)-bipyridyl ligands in dependence on the ratio of the starting components, we undertook the present study and report herein the preparation, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of 1D coordination polymer {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ (1), and two-dimensional (2D) coordination polymers {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]⋅0.5H2O⋅DMF}∞ (2), [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3), and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4) (Scheme ). The chiral layer is the robust structural motif generated through the tetrahedral sulfate anions and bipyridine linkers in 2-4. The potential porosity of 2-4 was estimated using PLATON facilities.

elements.content: Cadmium salts are carcinogenic and toxic. All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in Vaselin on a FT IR Spectrum-100 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Emission spectra were measured for monocrystals at room temperature on an Exitation YAG:Nd3+ laser, third harmonic generation, λ = 355 nm, duration = 10 ns, time repetition = 10 Hz.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Warning

Cadmium salts are carcinogenic and toxic. All reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on an Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH Vario El III elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained in Vaselin on a FT IR Spectrum-100 Perkin-Elmer spectrometer in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Emission spectra were measured for monocrystals at room temperature on an Exitation YAG:Nd3+ laser, third harmonic generation, λ = 355 nm, duration = 10 ns, time repetition = 10 Hz.

elements.content: NioxH2 (0.014 g, 0.1 mmol) and bpy (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved upon heating in the mixture CH3OH:DMF (3:1, 20 mL), and then, the hot solution of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in water (20 mL) was added. The resulting solution was stirred for ∼20 min, filtered off, and then slowly cooled to room temperature giving brown crystals. Yield: ∼50%. The crystals were soluble in alcohols, DMF, and partly in water. Found for C20H42N4O23S3Zn3 %: C, 23.98; H, 4.21; N, 5.46. Calcd %: C, 24.14; H, 4.26; N, 5.63. elements.content: X-ray data were collected at room temperature on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur diffractometer equipped with CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing Mo Kα radiation. The final unit cell dimensions were obtained and refined on an entire data set. All calculations to solve the structures and to refine the model proposed were carried out with the programs SHELXS97 and SHELXL97. Two carbon atoms of the cyclohexyl ring in 3 and three carbon atoms of the cyclohexyl ring in 4 are disordered over two positions with equal probabilities. The DMF molecule in 2 is disordered around a 2-fold axis. Compound 1 was refined as a racemic twin with the ratio of components of 0.39:0.61, and compound 3 was refined as a nonmerohedral twin with the ratio of the components of 0.574:0.426. In all structures, the C-bounded H-atoms were placed in calculated positions and were treated using a riding model approximation with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C), while the oxygen-bounded H-atoms were found from differential Fourier maps at an intermediate stage of the refinement, and their positions were constrained using the AFIX 83 instruction in SHELXL for oxime groups, while for the hydrogen atoms in water molecules the O–H and H···H distances were restrained to be 0.86(1) and 1.46(1) Å. These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(O). The X-ray data and the details of the refinement for 1–4 are summarized in Table , the selected geometric parameters are given in Table , and the hydrogen-bonding geometry is given in Table . The figures were produced using Mercury. The Kitaigorodskii packing index (PI) and solvent accessible voids (SAVs) were calculated using PLATON.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray data were collected at room temperature on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur diffractometer equipped with CCD area detector and a graphite monochromator utilizing Mo Kα radiation. The final unit cell dimensions were obtained and refined on an entire data set. All calculations to solve the structures and to refine the model proposed were carried out with the programs SHELXS97 and SHELXL97. Two carbon atoms of the cyclohexyl ring in 3 and three carbon atoms of the cyclohexyl ring in 4 are disordered over two positions with equal probabilities. The DMF molecule in 2 is disordered around a 2-fold axis. Compound 1 was refined as a racemic twin with the ratio of components of 0.39:0.61, and compound 3 was refined as a nonmerohedral twin with the ratio of the components of 0.574:0.426. In all structures, the C-bounded H-atoms were placed in calculated positions and were treated using a riding model approximation with Uiso(H) = 1.2Ueq(C), while the oxygen-bounded H-atoms were found from differential Fourier maps at an intermediate stage of the refinement, and their positions were constrained using the AFIX 83 instruction in SHELXL for oxime groups, while for the hydrogen atoms in water molecules the O-H and H⋅⋅⋅H distances were restrained to be 0.86(1) and 1.46(1) Å. These hydrogen atoms were refined with isotropic displacement parameter Uiso(H) = 1.5Ueq(O). The X-ray data and the details of the refinement for 1-4 are summarized in Table , the selected geometric parameters are given in Table , and the hydrogen-bonding geometry is given in Table . The figures were produced using Mercury. The Kitaigorodskii packing index (PI) and solvent accessible voids (SAVs) were calculated using PLATON.

Our previous results and the present study demonstrate that the system under investigation is sensitive to the ratio of the starting reagents. The competition between the neutral ligands, viz., bipyridine ligand and dioxime ligand, often results in the dioxime-free coordination polymers. Only double excess of NioxH2 in the starting reaction mixture allowed us to obtain the anticipated dioxime-containing polymeric compounds 2–4. The IR spectra for 1–4 are consistent with their chemical formulas. The characteristic bands of the bipyridine ligands are attributed to the medium intensity bands, at 1634 (1), 1658 (2), 1667 (3), and 1687 (4) cm–1, which correspond to the stretching vibrations CN. Vibrations of the aromatic ring are registered as strong bands at ∼1612–1608 cm–1, and medium intensity bands are registered at 1494–1492 cm–1 for all four complexes. Also, in all complexes, the band at 1420–1415 cm–1 is assigned to the δ(C–H) vibrations. Compounds 3 and 4 contain weak bands νs(CH2) at 2865 (3) and 2861 cm–1 (4) and νas(CH2) at 1956–1945 cm–1, typical for the saturated hydrocarbons. The bands at 1229–1225 and 976–970 cm–1 (2–4) can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of NO oxime group. The metal–ligand stretching vibrations ν(M-N) were observed at ∼550 and ∼425 cm–1. The crystallographically established symmetries of the sulfato groups are C 3v (monodentate coordination) in 1 and C 2v (bidentate-bridging coordination) in 2–4. The ν1–ν4 bands typical for the coordinated sulfate anion were observed in the 1020–990 and 635–468 cm–1 regions. The very strong band ν3 at ∼1100–1040 cm–1 and an average ν4 ∼635–600 cm–1 are split into several components, which indicates in favor of the bridging bidentate coordination of sulfate anion in 2–4. The splitting of ν2 bands indicates the lower symmetries than C 3v and C 2v as the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of sulfate anions are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules in 1 and to the oxygen atoms of the neutral oxime groups in 2–4 (Table ).

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectral Characterizations

Our previous results and the present study demonstrate that the system under investigation is sensitive to the ratio of the starting reagents. The competition between the neutral ligands, viz., bipyridine ligand and dioxime ligand, often results in the dioxime-free coordination polymers. Only double excess of NioxH2 in the starting reaction mixture allowed us to obtain the anticipated dioxime-containing polymeric compounds 2-4. The IR spectra for 1-4 are consistent with their chemical formulas. The characteristic bands of the bipyridine ligands are attributed to the medium intensity bands, at 1634 (1), 1658 (2), 1667 (3), and 1687 (4) cm-1, which correspond to the stretching vibrations CN. Vibrations of the aromatic ring are registered as strong bands at ~1612-1608 cm-1, and medium intensity bands are registered at 1494-1492 cm-1 for all four complexes. Also, in all complexes, the band at 1420-1415 cm-1 is assigned to the δ(C-H) vibrations. Compounds 3 and 4 contain weak bands νs(CH2) at 2865 (3) and 2861 cm-1 (4) and νas(CH2) at 1956-1945 cm-1, typical for the saturated hydrocarbons. The bands at 1229-1225 and 976-970 cm-1 (2-4) can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of NO oxime group. The metal-ligand stretching vibrations ν(M-N) were observed at ~550 and ~425 cm-1. The crystallographically established symmetries of the sulfato groups are C 3v  (monodentate coordination) in 1 and C 2v  (bidentate-bridging coordination) in 2-4. The ν1-ν4 bands typical for the coordinated sulfate anion were observed in the 1020-990 and 635-468 cm-1 regions. The very strong band ν3 at ~1100-1040 cm-1 and an average ν4 ~635-600 cm-1 are split into several components, which indicates in favor of the bridging bidentate coordination of sulfate anion in 2-4. The splitting of ν2 bands indicates the lower symmetries than C 3v  and C 2v  as the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of sulfate anions are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules in 1 and to the oxygen atoms of the neutral oxime groups in 2-4 (Table ).

elements.content: Compound 1 with the composition {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ crystallizes in the triclinic noncentrosymmetric P1 (no. 1) space group. The compound was refined as a racemic twin and has been converged with the Flack parameter of 0.392(11), which corresponds to the BASF value. The bpy molecules as bridging ligands generate two types of linear chains, anionic bpy-Zn(1)-bpy (chain A) and neutral bpy-Zn(2)-bpy (chain B) (Figure a), running along the b and c crystallographic axes, respectively. The atom Zn(1) is octahedrally trans-coordinated in a monodentate mode by sulfate anions and water molecules: Zn(1)–O distances range from 2.120(4) to 2.238(3) Å, and Zn(1)–N distances are 2.068(4) and 2.079(4) Å. The atom Zn(2) is octahedrally surrounded by one sulfate anion also coordinated in the monodentate mode and three water molecules. The Zn(2)–O distances range from 2.061(3) to 2.210(4) Å, and Zn(2)–N distances are 2.159(4) and 2.173(4) Å. The six-coordinated Zn(3) atom stands for [Zn(H2O)6]2+ aqua complex, and Zn(3)–O distances range from 2.034(4) to 2.169(4) Å (Table ). The bpy molecules coordinated to the Zn(1) and Zn(2) metal centers adopt slightly different conformations with the dihedral angles between the pyridine rings of 9.69 and 1.46°, correspondingly, being arranged approximately parallel to the bc plane. The fact that 1 crystallizes in a chiral P1 space group can be attributed to the asymmetry in the coordination environment of the Zn(2) metal center.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structures

Compound 1 with the composition {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ crystallizes in the triclinic noncentrosymmetric P1 (no. 1) space group. The compound was refined as a racemic twin and has been converged with the Flack parameter of 0.392(11), which corresponds to the BASF value. The bpy molecules as bridging ligands generate two types of linear chains, anionic bpy-Zn(1)-bpy (chain A) and neutral bpy-Zn(2)-bpy (chain B) (Figure a), running along the b and c crystallographic axes, respectively. The atom Zn(1) is octahedrally trans-coordinated in a monodentate mode by sulfate anions and water molecules: Zn(1)-O distances range from 2.120(4) to 2.238(3) Å, and Zn(1)-N distances are 2.068(4) and 2.079(4) Å. The atom Zn(2) is octahedrally surrounded by one sulfate anion also coordinated in the monodentate mode and three water molecules. The Zn(2)-O distances range from 2.061(3) to 2.210(4) Å, and Zn(2)-N distances are 2.159(4) and 2.173(4) Å. The six-coordinated Zn(3) atom stands for [Zn(H2O)6]2+ aqua complex, and Zn(3)-O distances range from 2.034(4) to 2.169(4) Å (Table ). The bpy molecules coordinated to the Zn(1) and Zn(2) metal centers adopt slightly different conformations with the dihedral angles between the pyridine rings of 9.69 and 1.46°, correspondingly, being arranged approximately parallel to the bc plane. The fact that 1 crystallizes in a chiral P1 space group can be attributed to the asymmetry in the coordination environment of the Zn(2) metal center.

elements.content: The adjacent chains are arranged in a crosslike fashion at the midpoints of the bpy ligands being at the interplanar separation within the range 3.25–3.74 Å, which is close to the 1/2a parameter, and form the rhombic channels (b × c = 11.19 × 11.44 Å) along the a-axis (Figure b). The [Zn(H2O)6]2+ cations are located within the structure channels and serve as structure-directing agents or templates. Compound 1 represents a rather rare example of crystal structure templated by hexaaquazinc(II) cation. The hydrogen bonds between the coordinated water molecules and the sulfate anions contribute to the crystal stability (Table ). Among the relative compounds, the anionic polymeric framework of the composition [Zn3(bpy)3(H2O)6(SO4)4]2– was reported within the structure {[Zn3(bpy)3(H2O)6(SO4)4](H2-bpy)·10H2O}∞, where the large cationic [H2-bpy]2+ molecules are present for charge neutrality of the overall structure.

elements.content: Compound 2 with the composition {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·0.5H2O·DMF}∞ crystallizes in the chiral monoclinic C2 space group. The Flack parameter of 0.007(17) indicates the true absolute configuration and enantiomeric purity of the single crystal despite the use of achiral starting components. The coordination environment of Zn(II) atom is shown in Figure . The divalent Zn atom adopts distorted N4O2-octahedral surrounding, coordinating two sulfate anions in monodentate modes in cis-positions, two bpy ligands in trans-positions, and the NioxH2 ligand in a chelate mode. The Zn–O bond lengths are equal to 2.041(3) and 2.102(4) Å, and the Zn–N bond lengths range from 2.181(4) to 2.237(5) Å (Table ). The rigidity of the equatorial platform is additionally provided by the OH···O hydrogen bonds between oxime hydroxyl groups as H-donors and sulfate anions as H-acceptors, O···O separations being 2.590(6) and 2.700(5) Å (Table ).

The Flack parameter of 0.007(17) indicates the true absolute configuration and enantiomeric purity of the single crystal despite the use of achiral starting components. The coordination environment of Zn(II) atom is shown in Figure . The divalent Zn atom adopts distorted N4O2-octahedral surrounding, coordinating two sulfate anions in monodentate modes in cis-positions, two bpy ligands in trans-positions, and the NioxH2 ligand in a chelate mode. The Zn-O bond lengths are equal to 2.041(3) and 2.102(4) Å, and the Zn-N bond lengths range from 2.181(4) to 2.237(5) Å (Table ). The rigidity of the equatorial platform is additionally provided by the OH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between oxime hydroxyl groups as H-donors and sulfate anions as H-acceptors, O⋅⋅⋅O separations being 2.590(6) and 2.700(5) Å (Table ).

elements.content: Extension of the structure through the sulfate bridges and the crystallographic 2-fold screw axis generates the homochiral right-handed helices (Figure a). The Zn···Zn distances through the SO4 2– anion measure 5.456 Å. The helical pitch is equal to the lattice parameter b being 9.230 Å. Adjacent helices are interconnected via the tethering bpy ligands to generate a chiral layer (Figure b). Neighboring homochiral layers stack parallel to the crystallographic a-axis with the partial interdigitation of the cyclohexyl rings. The porous solid 2 reveals the capability to accommodate polar protic (water) and aprotic (DMF) solvents in its different compartments. The water molecules anchor into the layer via OH···O hydrogen bonding with the coordinated sulfate anions (Table ). The interlayering DMF molecules intercalate between pyridine fragments of bpy ligands being held by the π–π stacking interactions (Figure c).

elements.content: The reported herein 2D polymer {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·0.5H2O·DMF}∞ (2) and the documented previously 1D ladder type polymer {[Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)] (NioxH2)·(H2O)3}∞ 6 represent the pseudosupramolecular isomers described by the same [M(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·(M = Zn, Cd) brutto-formula of the main structural unit but differ by the coordination modes of sulfate anion, being the μ1,μ2-bridging in the former and the μ2-bridging in the latter compound, and as a result differ by the dimensionality of their polymeric structures. Nevertheless, both of them due to coordination of bulky NioxH2 ligand to the metal center represent potentially porous materials with the voids filled by the polar solvents (H2O, DMF) in 2 or by the mixture of water and free NioxH2 in {[Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)] (NioxH2)·(H2O)3}∞ being held in the crystal lattices via hydrogen-bonding and π–π stacking interactions.

Nevertheless, both of them due to coordination of bulky NioxH2 ligand to the metal center represent potentially porous materials with the voids filled by the polar solvents (H2O, DMF) in 2 or by the mixture of water and free NioxH2 in {[Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)] (NioxH2)⋅(H2O)3}∞ being held in the crystal lattices via hydrogen-bonding and π-π stacking interactions.

elements.content: Compounds [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3) and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4), which differ by the radii of metal ions as well as by the conformation of the bpe ligand, crystallize in the monoclinic centrosymmetric P21/n and in the orthorhombic chiral P212121 space groups, correspondingly. The Flack parameter of 0.05(4) for 4 indicates true absolute configuration and enantiomeric purity within the single crystal. The coordination environments of Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms in 3 and 4 are shown in Figure . The bond distances in the coordination polyhedron in 3 are similar to 2 and reveal the proportional increase in 4 (Table ). In both structures, the bpe ligands adopt trans-conformations with practically equal C–CH2–CH2–C torsion angles and slightly different dihedral angles between the pyridyl rings, being −176.86 and 22.88° in 3 and −176.17 and 27.60° in 4, correspondingly.

elements.content: Similar to 2, the helices in 3 and 4 defined by the metal centers and linked by the tetrahedral sulfate anions, are exclusively left-handed in the chiral crystal 4 (Figure a), and both left- and right-handed in the centrosymmetric crystal 3. The helix in 3 is extended along the b direction with the helical pitch of 9.34 Å and along the a direction in 4 with the helical pitch of 9.58 Å. In both structures, the helical pitches are equal to the corresponding unit cell parameters. The tethering bpe ligands interconnect the left-handed helices into chiral layers in 4, and in 3, the left- and right-handed helices form the layers of opposite chirality. The organization of the chiral layer in these two structures is rather similar and strictly resembles 2 (Figure b,c). Although compounds 3 and 4 were isolated in the same crystallization conditions, the layers of opposite chirality constitute the achiral (3), and the layers of the same chirality result in chiral (4) architectures.

elements.content: In comparison with the bpy ligand in 2, the higher conformational flexibility of the bpe ligand in 3 and 4 provides its more perfect adjustment in the layer, accompanied by the strong π-stacking, as the rather short centroid–centroid contacts (<3.8 Å) (3.74 and 3.73 Å in two structures) indicate. The Kitaigorodskii packing indices and SAVs for 1–4 calculated using PLATON and summarized in Table indicate the possibility of potentially porous structures with the WAA geometry when the NioxH2 ligand coordinates to the metal center. Furthermore, the SAVs in the solvent-free structures 3 and 4 are comparable with 2 and registered in the interlayer space in the similar areas being occupied by DMF in 2 (Figure ).

elements.content: Coordination polymers especially those with d10 metal centers are widely investigated nowadays for photoluminescent properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), because of their high thermal stability and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of the organic material by metal coordination. Along with the others, our previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing Zn(II) and Cd(II) exhibit photoluminescent properties. The photoluminescent properties of 1–4 were investigated, and the results are present in Figure . Irradiation of crystalline samples of 1–4 with ultraviolet light (λex = 355 nm) at room temperature resulted in a broad emission with the maximum at 450 nm for 1 and red-shifted maxima at approximately 500 nm for 2–4.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Coordination polymers especially those with d10 metal centers are widely investigated nowadays for photoluminescent properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), because of their high thermal stability and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of the organic material by metal coordination. Along with the others, our previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing Zn(II) and Cd(II) exhibit photoluminescent properties. The photoluminescent properties of 1-4 were investigated, and the results are present in Figure . Irradiation of crystalline samples of 1-4 with ultraviolet light (λex = 355 nm) at room temperature resulted in a broad emission with the maximum at 450 nm for 1 and red-shifted maxima at approximately 500 nm for 2-4.

elements.content: The studied compounds differ in compositions and crystal packing and demonstrate the pronounced differences in the luminescent spectra, mainly in the intensity of emission and positions of the emission maxima. An obvious enhancement in the fluorescent intensity is observed for 1. Of specimens 1–4, sample 1 has a long afterglow of more than 100 μs; therefore, we attempted to measure its time-resolved luminescence spectra. Luminescence from sample 1 was studied in two regimes with the aim to separate the fast component of relaxation from the slow-decay component. In the first regime, the strobe gate of Boxcar with the duration of 10 μs covered the very beginning of the relaxation impulse of luminescence, while in the second regime, the same in duration strobe gate stood at 100 μs after start excitation. The spectral characteristics of the sample differ significantly in these two cases. This suggests that the spectral dependence is a superposition of several irradiative processes with substantially different times of relaxation. A more detailed study of the relaxation characteristics of the luminescence is planned to continue in the temperature range (77–300 K) that will help separate individual relaxation processes and give their quantitative characteristics.
elements.clean_text: The studied compounds differ in compositions and crystal packing and demonstrate the pronounced differences in the luminescent spectra, mainly in the intensity of emission and positions of the emission maxima. An obvious enhancement in the fluorescent intensity is observed for 1. Of specimens 1-4, sample 1 has a long afterglow of more than 100 μs; therefore, we attempted to measure its time-resolved luminescence spectra. Luminescence from sample 1 was studied in two regimes with the aim to separate the fast component of relaxation from the slow-decay component. In the first regime, the strobe gate of Boxcar with the duration of 10 μs covered the very beginning of the relaxation impulse of luminescence, while in the second regime, the same in duration strobe gate stood at 100 μs after start excitation. The spectral characteristics of the sample differ significantly in these two cases. This suggests that the spectral dependence is a superposition of several irradiative processes with substantially different times of relaxation. A more detailed study of the relaxation characteristics of the luminescence is planned to continue in the temperature range (77-300 K) that will help separate individual relaxation processes and give their quantitative characteristics.

elements.content: Four new polymeric coordination compounds with the compositions {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ (1), {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]·0.5H2O·DMF}∞ (2), [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3), and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4) were prepared and studied by single crystal X-ray method. The excess of NioxH2 in the starting reaction mixture gave rise to the anticipated WAA compounds 2–4, wherein the neutral auxiliary NioxH2 ligand coordinates in a chelate mode to the metal center. The availability of this bulky ligand imposes the asymmetry around the metal center and together with the tetrahedral sulfate-anion provides the structural motifs in the form of chiral layers. The mode of sulfate-anion coordination to the metal center as a terminal (1) or bridging (2–4) ligand makes the main impact on the dimensionality of the final coordination compounds, while the difference in the metal radii for Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms as well as in the flexibility of the bidentate bipyridine ligands proves not to be decisive for the final architecture, resulting in the formation of supramolecular isomers differing by the packing of the similar layers. All compounds reveal blue luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four new polymeric coordination compounds with the compositions {[Zn(H2O)6][Zn(SO4)2(H2O)2(bpy)][Zn(SO4)(H2O)3(bpy)]}∞ (1), {[Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpy)]⋅0.5H2O⋅DMF}∞ (2), [Zn(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (3), and [Cd(SO4)(NioxH2)(bpe)]∞ (4) were prepared and studied by single crystal X-ray method. The excess of NioxH2 in the starting reaction mixture gave rise to the anticipated WAA compounds 2-4, wherein the neutral auxiliary NioxH2 ligand coordinates in a chelate mode to the metal center. The availability of this bulky ligand imposes the asymmetry around the metal center and together with the tetrahedral sulfate-anion provides the structural motifs in the form of chiral layers. The mode of sulfate-anion coordination to the metal center as a terminal (1) or bridging (2-4) ligand makes the main impact on the dimensionality of the final coordination compounds, while the difference in the metal radii for Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms as well as in the flexibility of the bidentate bipyridine ligands proves not to be decisive for the final architecture, resulting in the formation of supramolecular isomers differing by the packing of the similar layers. All compounds reveal blue luminescent properties.

NioxH2 (0.014 g, 0.1 mmol) and bpy (0.016 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved upon heating in the mixture CH3OH:DMF (3:1, 20 mL), and then, the hot solution of ZnSO4·7H2O (0.029 g, 0.1 mmol) dissolved in water (20 mL) was added. The resulting solution was stirred for ∼20 min, filtered off, and then slowly cooled to room temperature giving brown crystals. Yield: ∼50%. The crystals were soluble in alcohols, DMF, and partly in water. Found for C20H42N4O23S3Zn3 %: C, 23.98; H, 4.21; N, 5.46. Calcd %: C, 24.14; H, 4.26; N, 5.63. cln_elements.content: Coordination polymers especially those with d10 metal centers are widely investigated nowadays for photoluminescent properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), because of their high thermal stability and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of the organic material by metal coordination. Along with the others, our previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing Zn(II) and Cd(II) exhibit photoluminescent properties. The photoluminescent properties of 1–4 were investigated, and the results are present in Figure . Irradiation of crystalline samples of 1–4 with ultraviolet light (λex = 355 nm) at room temperature resulted in a broad emission with the maximum at 450 nm for 1 and red-shifted maxima at approximately 500 nm for 2–4.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Coordination polymers especially those with d10 metal centers are widely investigated nowadays for photoluminescent properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs), because of their high thermal stability and the ability to affect the emission wavelength of the organic material by metal coordination. Along with the others, our previous studies have shown that coordination polymers containing Zn(II) and Cd(II) exhibit photoluminescent properties. The photoluminescent properties of 1-4 were investigated, and the results are present in Figure . Irradiation of crystalline samples of 1-4 with ultraviolet light (λex = 355 nm) at room temperature resulted in a broad emission with the maximum at 450 nm for 1 and red-shifted maxima at approximately 500 nm for 2-4.
